direction.raw_text: Darkness. Silence. After a long beat, we hear movement, confined and contained. We then hear the sound of a man, PAUL CONROY, groaning, making confused attempts at words. We hear his movement; short, abrupt shifting, ending almost immediately with the sound of his body banging against wood. He screams, though it's clear from the sound that his mouth is covered by something. After attempting to sit up, he immediately bangs his head against something. It's terribly warm and his breaths are labored. He attempts to move to his left and right, only to find that he is confined on those sides, as well. He frantically shifts about, only to discover, by touch, that he is encased in something. Something is very wrong, and he doesn't need to see to know that. Finally, we see him, lit by the flame of the Zippo he holds in his hands, which are bound together in front of him with rope. A rolled-up, dirty rag is tied tightly around his head, stretched across his mouth. Dried blood stains his hair and forehead. We see that he is lying in an old fashioned, wooden coffin. Nothing more than a few rotted-out planks of wood nailed together. Realizing the same, Paul is struck by an overwhelming, instant panic. With great difficulty, and while still holding the lit Zippo, Paul removes the muzzle from his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What...? What is this? His words become almost unintelligible as he flails about, though fear is understood in his every utterance. He screams aloud, but his voice is captured by the coffin walls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God! Help me!! Help me!! He kicks and slams his hands against the top and sides of the coffin, all to no avail. His violent movements cause small grains of sand to trickle in through the space between the sides and top of the coffin, as well as a small gap that exists between one of the coffin's broken wooden planks. Sweat cascades down the side of his neck, dripping from his dampened brow. The heat inside the extremely close confines of the coffin is stifling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody help me! Please!! Paul continues with his futile efforts to pry off the top of the coffin. The sides, the top, the bottom -- all are too thoroughly reinforced by the force of what surrounds the coffin. Sand. It becomes clear to him that he is buried. He tries his best to calm himself, though he has trouble catching his breath. It takes him some time, but he eventually achieves some semblance of calm. Getting a good look at him for the first time, we see that Paul is somewhere around 37 years old. Unshaven and physically unremarkable, he embodies the blue-collar American everyman. He coughs. The minimal amount of oxygen in the coffin makes it hard for him to breathe. His eyes widen a bit upon seeing an exposed, rusty nail. He tries desperately to use the nail to cut through the old, frayed ropes that bind his hands. Doing so is no easy task. The incredibly tight quarters makes his every action nearly impossible. After a lengthy struggle, the rope snaps. Paul quickly frees his hands. A small victory. Very small. The heat is unbearable. Paul takes off his button-down shirt, leaving him in a T-shirt. His body battles against the walls and the ceiling of the coffin with every move he makes. He tosses his button-down shirt down by his feet. His undershirt is drenched through with sweat. Still trying to calm himself, but having little success in doing so, Paul looks around the coffin. His feet, though only his body-length away, seem miles from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He looks at the top of the coffin, and then back at his feet. With great difficulty, he shifts his body so that his feet are pressed against the top of the coffin. He attempts to use his leg strength to push the top off of him, but it doesn't move even a millimeter. After several failed attempts, and with his legs exhausted, Paul drops his feet from the top of the coffin. He lay for a moment in silence, followed by an outburst of crying. Close to his head, on the corner of the floor, we see there's another broken plank. A small hole. He closes his cigarette lighter, extinguishing the flame. In total darkness, he continues to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this? With his sobbing slowly subsiding, the coffin soon grows eerily silent. The sound of Paul's labored breaths are all we hear, softened under the blanket of absolute darkness. After a beat, the silence is interrupted by a subtle buzzing sound. The muted sight of strange, blueish light flickers in the coffin, by Paul's feet. He is extremely startled. The buzzing continues, as does the minimal splashing of light. It's coming from underneath his discarded button-down shirt, down near his feet. He lights the Zippo to get a better look. Pulling the shirt away, he realizes that what he is hearing and seeing is the vibrating ring and display features of an older model cell phone. He frantically reaches for it, though the coffin is far too small for him to reposition himself so easily. To his dismay, the phone stops ringing. But, his efforts to reach it continue. He uses his feet to search for the phone. After some trouble finding it, he eventually locates it. Clamping the phone together between his clasped feet, Paul then painfully angles his body so that he can reach his feet with his hands and grab it. He is soon able to reach it. Immediately thereafter, he flips open the phone and puts the receiver in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . We see that there is a Text Message waiting for Paul on the phone. However, Paul barely notices. The time on the phone reads 6:12pm. While the numbers and display screen icons are familiar to Americans, all the words are in Arabic. What he does notices is that the phone barely has one bar of signal strength. Worse yet, there is only half of the battery life remaining. He tries to remember the Safe Number he was given. With the phone open and ready to be dialed, Paul struggles to recall the information.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, come on. What was it? Getting only two digits into dialing the number, he cannot remember much more and closes the phone. He wedges the lit Zippo into sand, which is compacted against a small hole in the wall of the coffin. Paul reaches into his pants pocket, frantically searching for something. He hastily removes a prescription pill bottle and a small, metal flask. Both are not what he was looking for. He then reaches to his back pocket and removes his wallet. It's empty. His license, his credit cards, his cash and, most importantly at that very moment, a piece of paper with the Safe Number written on it, are all missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Where the hell is it? Son of a...Come on! He screams aloud again, hoping greatly that someone can hear him. His frenzied maneuvering puts out the flame of the Zippo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Help me! Please! Somebody help me! His words barely make it pass the coffin walls. With the cell phone still in hand, and laboring to reclaim the breath he just expended, Paul turns to desperation. He dials the international code of 001, and then dials 911.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: answers almost immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: please hold. The Female 911 Operator places Paul on hold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Wait! Paul accidentally bangs the cap of the Zippo against the coffin wall, putting out the flame. She quickly returns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . What is your emergency?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . What's the problem, sir? Paul is so incredibly panicked that he has trouble remaining coherent. After a few sparks, the Zippo is re-lit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm buried. You have to help me. You have to help me, I can't breathe...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm buried in a coffin. Please help me! Send someone to find me...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir...slow down. What is your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul. Paul Conroy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Mister Conroy. Can you tell me your location?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I'm in a coffin. I don't know where. I'm scared. Please help me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're in a coffin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, it's, like, one of those old, wooden ones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you at a funeral home?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I don't know. No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are calling me right now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're buried in a coffin, where are you calling from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cell phone. There was an old cell phone in the coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're calling from your cell phone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. No. It's not mine, but yes, I'm calling from a cell phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was a cell phone in the coffin when you climbed in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't climb in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you end up in the coffin, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was put here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the coffin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Please send help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you're saying the coffin is buried?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so. It's...it's hot in here. I can't breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know your location, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you, I don't know. Somewhere in Iraq.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iraq?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I'm a truck driver, an American. I work for CRT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you a soldier, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Please, please listen to me. I'm a truck driver. I work for
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . I'm a civilian contractor working in Iraq. We were attacked in Baqubah, they...they... (STARTS CRYING) ...shot them. All of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shot who, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of the other drivers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you're saying this happened in Iraq? The country?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Please, you have to help me. They gave me a safety number to call, but I had it stored in my wallet and -- FEMALE 911 OPERATOR Mister Conroy, this is 911 emergency in Youngstown, Ohio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ohio?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. I'm not sure exactly how you called here if you're in another country, but if you'd like, I can patch you through to the Sheriff's Department.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sheriff's Department? No...you don't underst... (GIVING UP) ...forget it. Realizing that his conversation is both lengthy and useless, Paul ends the call. He checks the battery life on the phone. It still holds steady at two bars. He immediately dials another number, one that he can recall with ease. He again enters the 001 international code before making the call. Paul then dials his home phone. It rings several times, so far unanswered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, come on. Pick up. Please. After sitting through the agony of a few more rings, Paul is met with the answering machine. The voice of his young son, SHANE, is heard on the answering machine greeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for calling the Conroy's. We're not home right now. Please leave a message at the beep. Thanks. At the sound of the Beep, Paul leaves a frenzied, rambling message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Linda, honey, it's me. Listen, I need you to contact the National Guard right away. Or the Pentagon. Tell them we were attacked in the Diyala Provence, in Baqubah. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have to find me. Please help me, baby. Please help them find me. Paul hangs up. He dials his wife's cell phone right away. After several rings, her cell phone voice mail picks up. We hear the sound of Linda, Paul's wife, on her outgoing message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, this is Linda. Please leave a message. Thanks and have a great day. The Beep sounds and Paul immediately tears into his voice message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Linda, it's Paul. I need you to call me right away. This is an absolute emergency. Call the number that comes up on your phone. Call me at that number. If I don't answer, call the Pentagon or the F.B.I. I don't know what the hell is going on, but I'm buried in a box... Hearing himself say those last words gives him pause. The gravity of the situation fully takes hold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I can't breathe in here. Make sure you call me right away. Please, baby, please call me. Paul ends the call. He nervously looks at the amount of battery life remaining on the phone. Still holding strong at two bars. He notices the flickering light of the Zippo. It, too, appears to be using up small amounts of oxygen. He closes the lid, extinguishing the flame. Total darkness. Silence, save for Paul's increasingly heavy breaths. He begins to hyperventilate. He knows that preserving oxygen is paramount, so he does his best to calm himself. The healthy swig he takes from his flask helps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He flips open the cell phone. The light of the display screen partially illuminates his face and some of the coffin with a blueish hue. Paul again enters the overseas dialing code, this time dialing 411 information. The 411 OPERATOR answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What city and state, please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um...I don't know. The F.B.I., wherever they are. Paul reaches for his button-down shirt. Fishes for pens stashed in his lapel pocket, while keeping the phone pressed to his ear with his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have a specific city you'd like to be connected to, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care, any city. Just connect me to the F.B.I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, I have F.B.I. field offices listed in Boston, New York, Philadelphia, New Haven, Los Angeles, Chicago, Denver -- Paul cannot bear to listen any further to this list that seemingly never ends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anywhere! Any city, just connect me, please!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, sir, but I'm not allowed to do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine, um...Chicago. Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please hold for your number. Paul is transferred to an AUTOMATED MESSAGE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The number you requested, 312-421- 6700...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Paul writes the digits of the phone number on the top of the coffin with his pen. But, after the first three numbers, the pen stops working. He hurriedly reaches back into his shirt pocket to remove the other pen, which is actually a click-up pencil. Click-click-click-click. He writes the last seven digits, followed by the word "FBI."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...can be connected for an additional charge of twenty-five cents by pressing the number one. He presses the number one and is connected directly. After a few rings, SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chicago field office. Special Agent Harris.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Is this the F.B.I.?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes it is, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm calling from Iraq. I'm buried in the desert somewhere. I need you to help me -- SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS Whoa, whoa, sir. Slow down. When were you in Iraq?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now. I'm there now. I'm a truck driver for CRT. I've been here for nine months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I have your name please, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul Conroy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (saying it as he writes it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul Conroy. (back on the phone) Okay, Paul, explain to me what's going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Paul attempts to center himself so that he can accurately tell his story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. Me and a convoy of other drivers were delivering kitchen parts to a community center. As we got closer, a bunch of kids started throwing rocks at our trucks. Then an IED went off up ahead and blew up one of the other trucks. These guys came out from behind the houses with guns and started shooting everybody right there on the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were you shot at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know! (after a breath, calmer) I don't know. I was way in the back of the convoy. I must have got hit in the head with one of the rocks and got knocked out. That's the last thing I remember. But now I just woke up, and I was tied up and buried in a coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who put you there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess whoever ambushed us. Special Agent Harris sounds slightly skeptical of Paul's claims.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bunch of kids?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you're not listening. The kids threw the rocks at us, but then some Iraqi guys -- maybe insurgents, I don't fucking know -- popped out of nowhere and started shooting at us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you said they didn't shoot at you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They didn't, I don't know! But they shot them!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, you're going to have to stop shouting if -- PAUL I'm shouting because you're not listening! I need you to help me! Please!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmmm... Paul takes a moment to center himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you trace my call? GPS or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is it that they didn't shoot you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no idea. They didn't, that's all I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your social security number, Paul?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? Who cares? I'm buried in the middle of the fucking desert! Who cares what my social security number is?! I'm an American citizen. Just send someone to find me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know where you're ...lo...if...dy.. The cell phone starts breaking up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? What? I can't hear you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bet...un...near...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Suddenly, Special Agent Harris is not heard at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?! Hello?! Paul checks the phone's display, where he sees that the call has been lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit!! Cell phone service temporarily goes down. Paul lights the Zippo to help him see the cell phone screen. He tries to make a call, but nothing happens. He shakes the phone, moves it around the coffin, all in desperate hope that he will get a signal. He soon does. He looks at the number for the F.B.I. that he has written on the wall, thinking about calling them back. He then checks the battery life on his phone, which remains at two bars. Paul then decides to make a different call, this time to a phone number he has committed to memory: his employer back in the U.S., Crestin, Roland and Thomas (CRT). He closes the lid of the Zippo, extinguishing the flame. After a few rings, a CRT OPERATOR answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for calling Crestin, Roland and Thomas. How may I direct your call?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody, I need to talk to someone right away. It's an emergency.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is this, please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul Conroy. I'm a driver for you guys. I'm calling from Iraq. My convoy was attacked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, if this is a crisis situation you need to contact the Safety Number your were provided.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, I know, but I don't have it. They took it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who took it, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Iraqis, I think. I don't remember, I blacked out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to put you through to Alan Davenport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Davenport? Who's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Director of Personnel. Please hold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Personnel? No, I need to talk -- Paul is placed on hold. Synthesized soft rock plays in the background of the phone, maddening Paul further. Over the music, a CRT SPOKESMAN is heard, speaking a recorded testimonial during the on-hold message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At CRT, we work with our clients to provide effective and sustainable solutions to the challenges they face in our fast-growing, global economy. As the premiere... The message is interrupted by ALAN DAVENPORT's outgoing voice message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've reached Alan Davenport, personnel director at Crestin, Roland and Thomas. Please leave your name and number at the tone and I will return your call as soon as possible. The BEEP sounds. Paul is confused as to why he was patched through to someone in human resources, but leaves a message nevertheless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Paul Conroy, I'm from Hastings, Michigan. I'm a driver for CRT, and my convoy was ambushed...by insurgents or terrorists. I don't know. I don't know who it was. I'm stuck in the ground, buried in a coffin and I need help. Please send help. I'm begging you. I think I'm in Baqubah in the Diyala Provence. Please send help right away. I can't breathe in here. I can't...please. I'm begging you. I don't know who else to call. I... Paul notices that his phone has again lost signal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...fuck. Paul drops the phone to his side, the screen still emitting its glow. He explodes with a mixture of rage and fear. He screams and flails his feet and hands wildly, banging them against the walls of the coffin. His animalistic outburst causes the phone to close. The coffin returns to pitch black. After a long beat, Paul lights the Zippo, which remains wedged in the sand compacted against the small hole in the wall of the coffin. Paul takes a few moments to catch his breath. He looks again at the cell phone. Remembers receiving a Text Message. The icon on the phone's display indicates that he does, in fact, have an unread Text Message waiting for him. Paul quickly scrolls through the phone's menu, which is all written in Arabic, until he reaches what appears to be the Text Message option. Opening it, he sees a series of ten numbers. Using his click-up pencil, he scribbles the numbers onto the top of the coffin. Next to the number, he writes the word
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ?" Noticing that his phone has again picked-up a signal, he dials the number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . It rings once, but then the reception begins to falter. After only two rings, the call is ended. Paul's frustration mounts. He is barely able to fight off another fit of hysterics. He dials the number again. It rings once. A second ring. In the middle of the third ring, someone answers -- but they do not say anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Hello? Is anyone there? Hello? After a beat, Paul hears breathing on the other end of the phone. He also hears a discordance of background sound; the din of a room filled with Arabic-speaking men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Who are you? Please, you have to help me. Still, Paul's words are only met with slow, measured breaths.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is this? Hello? The person on the other end eventually speaks. An Iraqi man,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: talks forcefully and aggressively in broken English.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Breathe no breathe, American? Ah? Breathe no breathe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? I don't know what you're saying. Who is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: American can breathe no breathe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I can't breathe. Please get me out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, please get me out. Help me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no I'm not a soldier. I'm a truck driver. That's it. I'm not a soldier. I'm a contractor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Contractor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, that's right. A contractor. Not a soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blackwater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not for Blackwater. I'm not a security contractor. Truck driver, I'm a truck driver. That's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are American.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you are soldier. Despair falls upon Paul. It becomes clear that Jabir is responsible for all of this. As such, Paul crosses out the word "HELP?" Closes the lid of the Zippo, leaving only the cell phone display screen to illuminate his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm not. I'm here unarmed. But, you still shot at us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In head and in throat, so you tell no more lies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not lying! We were all drivers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drive what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trucks. The big trucks you see driving around with the supplies? That's us. That's me. We're not soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five million money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five million money tonight by nine
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: or you stay. Buried like dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five million dollars? From who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My family doesn't have five million dollars. If they did, I wouldn't be here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From Embassy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, yes, the Embassy will pay you. If you let me go, they'll pay you the money. Silence on the other end of the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a long beat) Nine PM, five million money. Jabir hangs up the phone, forcing Paul to instantly come to grips with the fact that he is being held hostage. He lays back in the coffin, shell-shocked. Physically spent, the cell phone falls from his hands and onto the floor. The display screen casts a dim light throughout the coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Zippo lights. Paul holds it in his hand, using it to illuminate the inside of the coffin. He attempts to push it into its now customary resting place, but the sand has loosened, making it difficult for the Zippo to stay in place. It almost falls to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Looking around, Paul sees there is a crack between two planks, located on the opposite wall of the coffin. He wedges the lit Zippo into the crack. With his hands now free, Paul haphazardly positions himself so that his back is facing the top of the coffin. His every move is arduous; the claustrophobic nature of the coffin bearing down on him. Paul positions his bent knees underneath his chest, with his shins and feet pressed against the bottom of the coffin. Using the strength of his legs, he attempts to lift the top off the coffin with his back. Trickles of sand fall in from the side of the coffin, sprinkling against the wooden base. He fails, only to immediately try again. And again. And again. Exhaustion sets in. Staring ahead, the phone sits in front of him. He notices that the battery life bars are still at one solid and one blinking. He grabs the cell phone, staring at it, trying to think of someone else to call. The battery life is limited. Every call has to count. He tries to remember some phone numbers, but has trouble recalling the information.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, what's her number? He cannot remember the number he's thinking of. He notices that the flame of the Zippo flickers, indicating its use of his much-needed oxygen. Paul closes the lid, extinguishing the flame. A second later, we see him, lit by the cell phone display screen. He dials the international code for the United States, followed by 411 information.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What city and listing, please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hastings, Michigan. I'm looking for Donna Mitchell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have two Donna Mitchells, sir. One on Federal Road and one on Ardmore Avenue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ardmore Avenue...I think. Yeah. Shit, I don't know. Just give me that one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ardmore Avenue?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Ardmore Avenue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please hold for your number. Paul is switched to an AUTOMATED MESSAGE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The number you requested, 269-948- 1998 can automatically be dialed for a charge of twenty-five cents by pressing the number one. Paul writes Donna's number and name on the top of the coffin and then presses the number one. He is connected. Her phone rings and rings. Paul's frustration is evident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on! Where the hell is everyone? The phone rings some more. Paul checks the battery life -- still at one and a half bars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: eventually answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Hearing her voice, Paul hurriedly places the phone to his ear.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fooled you. I'm not really home. But if you leave a message, I'll get back to you as soon as I get in. Bye-bye. His hand falls to his forehead, defeated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donna, I need to talk to Linda. It's an absolute emergency. Have her call me. Use star sixty-nine and find out the number I'm calling from and have her call me... Donna picks up the phone.

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I haven't talked to her all day. Call her cell phone.

direction.raw_text: Are you near a computer or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh...yeah. Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turn it on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look up the number for the State Department for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just heading out to the supermarket. I really don't have

direction.raw_text: Donna, please, please, please -- just get me the number.

direction.raw_text: Is everything alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Everything is not alright! So, please, just look up the number.

direction.raw_text: Don't fucking yell at me, Paul.

direction.raw_text: I'm not yelling!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes you are. Just like you did last year at the cookout. I'm not going to tolerate -- PAUL (EXPLODING) Just get me the fucking number!! Get me the number, get me the number!! Donna hangs up on him. Realizing this, Paul bangs his fists and claws at the top of the coffin, bloodying some of his fingers and knuckles in the process. He violently tosses and turns and screams at the top of his lungs, like an animal trapped in a cage. Tears spray from his eyes as spit shakes free from his mouth by the force of his shudder. He eventually calms quite a bit. Sniffing away tears and taking notice of the damage he's done to his hands, Paul slows his breathing as best he can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He lies there, motionless. The silence is almost comforting. Paul closes his eyes, regretfully accepting what appears will be his inescapable fate. After a beat, he calls Donna back. Knowing it is Paul calling, she answers right away, attitude at the ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? It takes every ounce of Paul's being to keep himself from going off the deep end. He takes a beat to compose himself and then finally offers a very delicate and deliberate response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donna, I'm very sorry I yelled. But, I'm only going to ask you once more to get me this number. If you don't get me this number, I'm going to die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have time to explain. Please...the number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on. We hear Donna put down the phone. In the b.g., we hear the sound of keys being pressed on a computer keyboard. After a beat, she picks the phone back up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay...State Department. It's 202- 134-4750.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Paul writes the number on the top of the coffin, beneath the man others. He writes the initials "S.D." next to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell's going -- Paul hangs up on Donna mid-sentence. He dials the number the State Department right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: answers after a few rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: United States Department of State.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm an American citizen, working in Iraq. I've been taken hostage. I need to speak to someone right away.

direction.raw_text: Where are you calling from, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From Iraq. I'm a truck driver for
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crestin, Roland and Thomas. We were attacked and now I'm being held for ransom.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I'm buried somewhere.

direction.raw_text: You're buried?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, in a coffin, a wooden box. It's an old coffin, I think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you try contacting the military out there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have the number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What number?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was given a number to call, a safety number. But the people took it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The people holding you hostage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know...hold on. Let me connect you...hold on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Wait... Paul is placed on hold. As he waits, his eyes wander around the coffin. He looks at the numbers he has written. After a moment, REBECCA BROWNING, a State Department official, picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rebecca Browning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, hello. I was just informed of your situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, my situation. I'm running out of time and you people keep putting me on hold. What the hell is wrong with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be sorry. Just help me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just have a few questions for you, Mister Conroy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got to be kidding me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's important that I get this information. It will make a rescue
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait, wait, wait...how did you know my name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never gave you my name. I don't think I gave it to the other guy, either. Rebecca is silent on the other end of the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell is going on right now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a beat) We received a call from a representative at CRT. You left him a message?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He contacted us right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, since you know what the hell is going on, what have you done to get me out of here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's little we can do from Washington.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, that's it? I'm just supposed to rot in here because there's little you can do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need to know where you were when your convoy was ambushed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the Diyala Provence. In Baqubah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. And has contact been made with the kidnappers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. The guy told me that he wants five million dollars by nine o'clock tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or else...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or else he'll bring me to Sea World. What do you think, lady? Even faced with Paul's sarcasm, Rebecca remains stolid. Professional.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll do everything we can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you'll pay them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. That we can't do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait...what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the policy of the United States government to not negotiate with terrorists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To hell with that! It's easy for you to worry about policy, you're sitting in an air conditioned office somewhere, probably finishing up your sandwich from lunch. You're not the one stuck in a coffin, buried in the God damn desert!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand your frustration -- 29.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frustration? Lady, I'm going to fucking die in here. Understand that! Rebecca is silent on the other end of the phone. Paul wonders if she is still there. The idea of being alone again scares him terribly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Worried, Paul lights the Zippo. The reflection of the flame dances on his frightened eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here. Momentary relief. After a beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, then say something. Tell me how you're going to get me out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the number on the phone you're calling from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Did it come up on your end?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. It's listed as unavailable. Do this -- take down this number. Paul takes out his pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Paul writes the number onto the top of the coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dan Brenner. He's the commander of the Hostage Working Group over in Iraq.

direction.raw_text: . Paul writes "D. BRENNER" next to Dan's phone number.

direction.raw_text: Hostage Working Group?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We formed it in 2004 to deal with situations such as yours. Paul shakes his head in disgust.

direction.raw_text: Situations. I love how you keep calling it that.

direction.raw_text: Did you write down the number?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.

direction.raw_text: Good. Hold on, I'll connect you with him now. He should be expecting you.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine.

direction.raw_text: I'm transferring you now. Rebecca's gone. Paul waits. Several beeps sound as he's being transferred. Paul hears a faint sound coming from behind him, outside the coffin. While the beeps continue to sound, he lights the Zippo, circumspectly looking behind him. He doesn't see anything. With the Zippo still lit, Paul takes a deep, centering breath, followed by another. A few more long beeps pass before a ring is heard. After two rings, DAN BRENNER answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brenner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dan Brenner? Dan is quick to figure out who it is that must be calling him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this Paul Conroy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, yes it's me. It's Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul, I was informed of what's going on. I want you to know that we're already working on trying to get you out of there.

direction.raw_text: . Paul is relieved. His first glint of hope has appeared. Tears of joy instantly escape his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thank you, God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was told that we have until 9pm. Is that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what he said.

direction.raw_text: Alright. That doesn't give us a whole lot of time. And just so I have this right, the kidnappers buried you in the ground?

direction.raw_text: Yeah, in an old, wooden coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. My guess is that since you're able to get a cell signal, you're no more than a few feet underground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Maybe.

direction.raw_text: Less than half.

direction.raw_text: Okay. You have to conserve that battery. Our best bet of finding you is by tracking your cell signal. Is the ringer set on a sound or vibrate?

direction.raw_text: Vibrate.

direction.raw_text: Press and hold down the asterisk key to change it to a ring tone. It will use less power.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a lighter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.

direction.raw_text: Use it to look around for markings, a logo -- whatever you can find.

direction.raw_text: Won't it use up oxygen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not much. Don't worry about that now. Try to find -- PAUL It's really dark in here without it.

direction.raw_text: I understand, Paul. Try to find anything in there that might indicate where that coffin was made.

direction.raw_text: You guys have to hurry.

direction.raw_text: We're working as fast as we can, Paul.

direction.raw_text: Do you know if there were any other survivors?

direction.raw_text: From your convoy?

direction.raw_text: Yeah.

direction.raw_text: That's still unclear at this point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wanted to do right by my family. That's all. (MORE)

direction.raw_text: I didn't know it was going to be like this over here.

direction.raw_text: I don't think any of us did. While on the phone with Brenner, Paul gets another call coming in. He checks the display and reads the number. Matching it against a number he wrote on the top of the coffin, he sees that is Jabir calling.

direction.raw_text: It's him. He's calling.

direction.raw_text: The kidnapper?

direction.raw_text: Yeah. What do I do?

direction.raw_text: Yeah.

direction.raw_text: Give it to me.

direction.raw_text: Give me the number first. The phone has rung several times. Paul fears that Jabir may hang up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's going to hang up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take the call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take the call. Now. Paul complies with Dan's demand and switches to the other line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two hour, six minute. Paul looks at his watch. Indeed, he has but two hours and six minutes until the time reaches 9pm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to give me more time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You talk to embassy? They give money?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. No. I talked to...someone. Government. They said that they won't pay the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No pay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. They said that they don't negotiate with terrorists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terrorists? I am terrorist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. You are terrorist, you son of a bitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are terrified, so I am terrorist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did I ever do to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. I'm here because it's a job, to make money. That's it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have job until you come. Now, my family have nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not my fault! Jabir retorts with a spirited conviction similar to Paul's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nine, one, one was not my fault, but still you are here! Saddam was not my fault, but still you are here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you, I'm only here to work. To help rebuild.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rebuild what you destroyed. Paul cannot handle his stress any longer. He begins to crumble under the pressure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop! Just please, stop! I'm just a guy. I'm just a truck driver. Okay? I'm nobody that makes decisions about anything. I just want to go home. Silence from the other end of the phone for an extended period of time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You make video, ransom video. This surprisingly comes as good news to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Please. Get me out of here and I'll make the video.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. You make video now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What...? How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You use video on phone. Paul's hopes are dashed. His sanguine head falls back onto the coffin floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Near foot. You read note near foot in box. Paul shines the flame of his Zippo lighter toward his feet. He doesn't see anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where? I don't see -- JABIR Near foot. Read note inside box. Paul repositions his legs as best he can. He can vaguely see the corner of a small metal box, partially sticking out of a broken plank on the bottom of the coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The video...if I make it, will you let me go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only if we get money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody's going to pay five million dollars for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We take less. One million money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they pay it, will you let me go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a beat) One million money. Jabir hangs up, ending the call. Paul sits motionless for a moment, soaking in all that Jabir has just told him. He again looks down toward his feet. He can see the protruding corner of the metal box, but it's positioned in such a way that it will clearly not be easy for him to reach it. Paul then tries to clasp the box with his feet, but after several unsuccessful attempts, he realizes that a new strategy is necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He makes efforts to reposition himself in the coffin, so that his head and feet will ultimately switch places. He struggles, inch by troubled inch, to make this maneuver. Sweat pours down the side of his face. The extremely tight quarters of the coffin make the repositioning nearly impossible. After expending a great deal of energy doing so, Paul eventually completes the turn of his body. He examines the small, rusted metal box. On it is a cartoon picture of a small Arab boy and girl playing with a red rubber ball. Skeptical at first, Paul carefully examines the box and shakes it gently. Items are heard rummaging inside. He carefully opens it. A fluorescent green light shines from inside. Paul looks inside and finds a lit, green glow stick, fluorescing brightly and now illuminating much of the coffin. He closes the lid of the Zippo. Removes the stick. Looking into the small box again, he finds several other items: a small, disused flashlight; a second, unlit glow stick; a jackknife; and lastly, a folded piece of paper. He slowly unfolds the piece of paper. We see that his ransom message is written in an unintelligible mix of English and Arabic. Paul shakes his head and lets out a sigh of disgust. He crumbles up the paper into a ball and listlessly drops it to his side. He covers his face with his hands, his labored breaths echoing in his palms. Under the low-light of the green glow stick, Paul picks up the phone and dials his home. Per usual, he gets the answering machine. His son, Shane, is heard on outgoing message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for calling the Conroy's. We're not home right now. Please leave a message at the beep. Thanks. Paul's eyes well up with tears. He smiles at the sound of his son's voice. The Beep is heard. Paul hangs up without leaving a message. He looks at the time. It's 7:02pm. Battery life is holding steady at one and a half bars. He remembers something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit. Paul presses and holds down the shortcut button on the phone that changes the ringer from vibrate to an audible tone. The glow stick begins to slowly fade. Paul dials Dan Brenner. After a few rings, Dan answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's his number... Paul presses the green key, bringing up the last numbers dialed and received.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on. Alright, go ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's 07902-24-921. Dan says something to someone who is in the room with him, and then returns his attention to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is huge. Unless they're using a cloned line, we should be able to find where this is coming from in minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about me? Can you track my cell signal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're having a lot of trouble with yours. Seems to be an EDS line, probably through one of the Egyptian carriers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does that mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That...it's not going to be easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wants me to make a ransom video.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Hold off for as long as you can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it's going to get me out of here, I'm making it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last thing we want is for this to end up all over Al Jazeera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We? Paul becomes angry, again sensing that more emphasis is being placed on containing the situation than rescuing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This can't turn into an international incident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all you people care about! But what about me? Don't you care about me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We do. That's why we're -- PAUL No you don't! You people don't care about any of us. I've had eight friends killed out here, six of them today. We don't have any guns, any armor. Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell that to the people who put me in this box! Tell that to the people who shot my friends!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're doing the best we can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you're not. All you people understand are your secret plans and your back room politics. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I were some diplomat or something, maybe even a hostage working group leader -- or whatever your fancy title is, I'd be out of here by now. Wouldn't I? But I'm not, so I'm just supposed to keep my mouth shut and die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need you to stay focused, Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck you. Dan's heard enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul, listen to me: finding you is our primary concern. Bottom line. And we're searching just as hard as we would be for a four-star general, so don't literally waste your breath suggesting otherwise. Paul does not respond at first. Dan's retort clearly has an effect on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are they? The people who put me here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're just that -- people. No different from you and me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm no terrorist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither are they.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you were homeless, starving...actually, I take that back. If your family was homeless and starving, what would you do for them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't kill someone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you be sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What difference does it make?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're criminals, desperate ones at that. They don't care about anything other than getting the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So pay them, then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trust me, if it was an option, I would do that in a heartbeat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many others have there been?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since I got here? Hundreds. Journalists, contractors, soldiers...hundreds have been taken. It's one of the only functioning businesses out here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many have you rescued? Dan is reluctant to answer the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not many.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me their names.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any of them. Make me know they really do matter to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark White.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who was Mark White?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A kid from New Hampshire. Twenty- six years old. Med student. Came over here to help out local doctors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Insurgents grabbed him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About three weeks ago. Paul writes "MARK WHITE" on the top of the coffin, below the list of phone numbers. He circles the name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You remember his name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember all their names.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (afraid to ask) Did he...? Is he...? The glow stick begins to fade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Yeah, Paul, he's alive. Hearing this affords Paul some semblance of relief. Paul shakes the glow stick, returning it to its full strength.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Home. Probably happy to be back at school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to get out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We found him; we'll find you, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We already have a solid lead on the number you gave us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A unit's on it's way over there now. This news calms Paul's nerves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's...that's good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What should I do in the meantime?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's hard, but try to relax. The more worked up you are, the more air you're going to use.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't help it. I'm always anxious. I take pills for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have them with you? Paul checks his pants pockets. He removes a small, orange pill bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take them. You need to preserve your oxygen level any way you can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is your Zippo still lit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel nauseous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to calm down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you need to save that battery. We're expecting some intel in about ten minutes. Call me back then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just hang in there, Paul. The glow stick begins to slowly fade. Paul shakes it, causing it to brighten only momentarily before dimming again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. I'm trying. Dan ends the call. Paul lets out a deep breath, finding it difficult to lay claim to its replacement. He looks at his watch. It's now 7:18pm. The ticking sound of the second hand turning is inordinately loud, due to the extreme silence of the coffin. Just then, the cell phone rings. Checking the number on the display, Paul sees that it is Jabir. Paul answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you make video?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Jabir yells something in Arabic to the other Iraqi men we hear in the background. Collectively, they do not sound pleased. Slightly panicked, in fact, though it is difficult to tell for sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You make video!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me out and I'll make it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! You make video now. In box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't. I can't read the paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make video now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't. I don't know what you want me to say. I can't read the paper. Jabir is heard speaking with the men we hear arguing in the background. Although they speak in Arabic, it is clear from their tone that they are becoming worried and increasingly hostile. Jabir returns his attention back to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You make video now. Jabir ends the call. Paul closes the phone to help conserve battery life. He then reopens the phone and scrolls through the menu options. Everything is written in Arabic. He eventually comes across an icon with a movie camera -- the video function. He turns it on. Looks at himself though the viewfinder. After a beat, he closes the phone, clearly frustrated and growing more panicked. His breaths grow heavy and rapid, utilizing a great deal of oxygen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm never getting out of here. Paul begins to freak out, restlessly squirming inside the coffin and pressing against the sides and top. The glow stick fades out almost completely, offering very little light. Paul shakes it, but with no change to its brightness. Moments later, it dies. Paul tries the flashlight. Click-click. Click-click. Nothing. He bangs it a few times with his hand. The white light turns on, but quickly turns back off. He twists the top, which causes the flashlight to switch bulbs. A red beam emits momentarily. Paul twists the top again and gives the flashlight a few good whacks. It turns on. White light shines dimly on his face. He takes a breath. In efforts to calm himself, he once again removes the orange pill bottle from his pocket. He pours two into his hand. He then removes his small, metal alcohol flask from his back pocket and takes a large swig, swallowing the two pills in the process. Still, Paul's heavy, labored breathing continues. He drops four additional pills into his and swallows them with yet another generous pull from the flask. He sits and waits. Nothing is happening, except that his extremely limited time keeps passing. After a moment, Paul picks up the cell phone. He holds it in front of him, hesitant to make a call. After some consideration, he dials. After a few rings, a NURSING HOME NURSE answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mountain View Nursing Home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was hoping I could speak with Maryanne Conroy, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um...okay. Ah...let me bring the cordless phone to her room. Hold on a moment, please. We hear the Nurse walk down the tiled corridor floor. She soon reaches Paul's mother's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Misses Conroy, you have a telephone call, dear. Here, you can use this phone. Paul's mother, MARYANNE, answers. Her voice is pleasant but confused. It's clear that she suffers from advanced stages of Alzheimer's Disease.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom...it's Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Paul, Mom. Your son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My son?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay, Mom. How are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your son, Mom. It's Paulie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paulie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Remember? We lived over on Colfax Street, in the duplex. Remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paulie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this Paulie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is, Mom. It's Paulie. How's everything at the home?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very nice. Your father and I have been playing gin rummy every night. It's almost too much for Paul to take. He cries silent tears over a heartbroken smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah...I don't think Pop's there with you, Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you doing, sweetie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not very good. This...uh, this may be the last time I talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's nice, honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you get the flowers I sent a few months ago?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flowers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I sent...never mind. Listen, I...I'm going to go now. I just wanted to talk to you, you know, just to say bye. I love you, Mom. Maryanne doesn't respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear me? Mom? I told you...do you want to tell me you
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, dear. Your father and I have been playing gin rummy every night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a beat) Okay, Mom. Tell Pop I said hi. Paul ends the call and instantly begins crying his heart out. He lays there, sobbing relentlessly. After a long beat, the cell phone rings. Decidedly different than his past reactions to an incoming call, Paul seems hopelessly disinterested. The ring is maddening. He mindlessly presses the shortcut button, resetting the ring to vibrate mode. He eventually picks up the phone, but there is not anyone on the other end. It's then that he sees that it was not a call that came in, but instead was a picture message. Pressing what appears to be the Accept button, the incoming picture begins to download. Several seconds later, the picture downloads and an image appears on the display of Paul's cell phone. It's of a woman
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: bound and gagged, a gun pressed against the side of her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no. No, no, no! Paul frantically dials the number to reach Jabir. As soon as the phone connects, Paul begins his desperate plea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Video make?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let her go. Please. Please don't hurt her. The Woman is heard in the background of Jabir's phone, crying muffled words through her muzzled mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We shoot her if you no make video.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! No, please no shoot. No shoot her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You get money. American million.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will, I promise. Just don't shoot her. She's a mother, she's got two kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two kids?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. She has two kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have five. Now only one. You make video. Now!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No wait!! I give three seconds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't read the paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Wait!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what you want me to say!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay! Okay, I'll make the video. Just, please, don't shoot. Jabir does not fire his gun. Paul attempts to catch his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need to hang up to make the video. Okay? Is that okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have three minute to send video.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jabir hangs up, ending the call. Paul reaches for the balled-up piece of paper that has the ransom script written on it. It takes some trouble for him to grab it, but he is soon able to. Placing the flashlight next to the paper, Paul is again reminded of the incoherent nature of the script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (re: the script) Fuck... He drops the paper to his side and opens the phone, setting it to the video record function. He places the flashlight close to his face so as to make his image more visible on the small, phone display screen. He presses the record button.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (speaking at the phone) My name is Paul Conroy. I'm an American citizen from Hastings, Michigan. I'm a civilian truck driver for Crestin, Roland and Thomas. I've been taken hostage somewhere in Iraq...and I need one million dollars by nine o'clock tonight, Baghdad time, or else I'll be left to die in this coffin I'm buried in. I've been told that if... The flashlight goes out. Paul continues speaking in the darkness. After a few quick smacks, the flashlight turns back on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...the money is paid, I will be let go. If it's not, I will die in here. These threats are real and will be followed through on. Trying to think of more to say, Paul soon opts for not saying anything further. He saves the message and then sends it to Jabir. We see that the screen displays an icon confirming the video has been sent. Paul places the phone on his chest. Still rubbing his temples, his eyes begin to flutter a bit. He tries to control his breathing and remain calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He opens the phone and displays the photo of the Woman. He stares admiringly at her, hoping dearly that she will not be harmed. The effects of the anxiety pills finally taking effect, his eyes soon close and he drifts off to sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darkness once again. We hear the sound of Paul slowly awaking, followed the sight of Zippo sparks. It doesn't catch. The second glow stick is snapped, illuminating the coffin with a fluorescent green hue. Paul starts to move, but suddenly freezes. His eyes widen. His pupils dilate. Something is clearly very wrong, though we cannot see what. His eyes slowly shift downward, as if watching something move down his body. Beads of sweat form across his brow. His measured breaths are held for as long as they can be. Moving excruciatingly slow, Paul lowers the glow stick toward what he is looking at. A shape moves across his stomach, underneath his T-shirt. Paul's eyes are fixed on whatever it may be. He cautiously, slowly, moves the glow stick even closer. The shape disappears just as the light of the glow stick shines on whatever it may be. Still, Paul does not dare make any sudden move. Paul's pant leg moves slightly, starting at the top, slowly undulating toward his cuff. Paul leans the glow stick in further. And further. Carefully. Moving a millimeter at a time. He shifts the position of his head slightly, charily, to see next to his feet. He leans in even closer with the glow stick. But then -- -- his wary movement comes to immediate stop. It's a snake. A two-foot, saw-scaled viper. It has positioned itself in the corner of the coffin, inches from Paul's feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . His terror evident, Paul very slowly pulls his feet back toward his upper body, away from the snake. The confined space offers little room for safety. The snake turns its muscled neck to face Paul. Their eyes meet for the first time. The snake hisses, poised to strike at any moment. Paul raises his foot. Steels himself. Prepares to preempt the snake with a solid stomp. A more sensible plan soon prevails. After lowering his foot, Paul cautiously removes the flask from his pocket. Slowly unscrews the top. Splashes a small amount of alcohol on the floor, close to the snake. The snake recoils slightly, but then menacingly twists itself into a new posture, ready to attack. Paul lowers the Zippo to the small puddle of alcohol. After a few sparks -- -- it lights. A flash-fire. The snake flails and hisses wildly at the other side of a small fire wall. The flame soon goes out. Paul moves fast. Throws more alcohol, this time some of it lands on the snake itself. He places the already lit Zippo against the puddle of alcohol near the snake. Another flash-fire, this time burning the snake. It hisses loudly. Threateningly. It swings back and forth, challenging the small wall of fire. The fire soon extinguishes. The snake burrows into the hole from where it likely entered the coffin, disappearing into it with haste. Paul hurriedly stuffs the hole with his discarded button-down shirt. He then pours a small amount of alcohol over the shirt and temporarily puts the flask on the ground, but does not screw the cap on securely. He then wedges the lit Zippo between a small space between two wooden planks. With the snake situation handled, Paul finally lets out a sigh of relief. Rubs his eyes. Tries to regain his faculties. Looks over the list of phone numbers written above him. Suddenly, the cell phone vibrates. Paul frenziedly searches for it, but he cannot find it. He then notices it has fallen into the small hole near his feet, out of his reach. He makes several attempts to grab the phone with his feet, but he is unable to do so. It continues to ring. His next efforts involve repositioning himself in the coffin so that he completely turns to face the opposite end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Struggling through each move, Paul painstakingly begins to turn himself. While turning, however, he inadvertently kicks the Zippo from the side of the coffin -- landing it on the floor, up against the glow stick -- and knocks over the flask. We see that the flame of the Zippo slowly melts the plastic glow stick, causing it to dim slightly. Worst still, and completely unbeknownst to Paul, a stream of alcohol slowly makes its way from the flask and toward the flame of the lighter, threatening to set the coffin ablaze. Inch by inch, the flammable spirit gets closer. Still in the midst of his repositioning, Paul looks back and sees the alcohol nearing the flame. In a panic, he attempts to reach and grab the Zippo. But, he finds himself stuck in the middle of the coffin. He can't budge either way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, no!! Desperately straining every muscle in his body, he extends his arm backward toward the Zippo, hoping to move it away from the spilled alcohol. He still can't reach it, yet he tries with all his might. The phone stops ringing. He has missed the call. He tries blowing at the flame, but his head is too far away and his breath is not strong enough to do much more than cause it to flicker. With the alcohol now mere inches away from the flame, Paul reaches for his shoe. His odd positioning makes reaching his foot almost impossible. He struggles to undo the laces and remove it from his foot. With his face beet red from the force of his strain, Paul finally removes his shoe. The mere inch of leg room this creates allows him to slide his leg out from under him. The trail of alcohol is just about to come into contact with the flame -- -- but Paul deftly maneuvers his body just in time to awkwardly kick the Zippo out of the way and close the lid. Paul breaths an enormous sigh of relief as he sits in the dim light of the damaged glow stick. He notices another hole in the coffin. As a precaution, he stuffs it with the cloth that had previously been used to gag him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Just as he is about to grab the phone, he hears what appears to be the faint sound of a Muslim call to prayer being announced over the citywide PA system. The sound barely makes its way through the hundreds of pounds of sand that envelop the coffin. A sign of hope, as well as a point of reference for his location -- albeit a very vague one. He listens further as the call to prayer continues. The light of the glow stick dims further. Paul then opens his phone. Sees that he missed Jabir's call. He starts to call Jabir back, but stops. He instead navigates through the various display menus. He soon reaches what appears to be the Tools Menu, though it's difficult to tell because everything is written in Arabic. He becomes frustrated as he fails to find what he is looking for. On the verge of mental surrender, he sees something that gives him pause. A smile crosses his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (re: the phone screen) There you are. We see, on the display of the phone, that Paul has found a listing of languages. He scrolls past many -- "FRANCAIS, DETSCHE, ESPANOL" -- stopping at "ENGLISH." Presses the button, instantly making all the text on the screen readable. He quickly navigates to the Tools menu. Scrolls down. Locates the number of the cell phone he is using. He scribbles the number onto the top of the coffin. Then a second pass, making it bolder than the others. Paul then dials his wife's cell phone. After only a few rings, he is met by her voice mail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Hi, this is Linda. Please leave a message. Thanks and have a great day. The beep sounds, and Paul frantically proceeds right into his message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Linda, here's the number for the phone. I just found it out. It's
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . You have to use the international calling code first. (MORE)
direction.name: direction
