direction.raw_text: Please call me as soon as you get this. I love you...I love you. Call me right away. Please. Paul hangs up. He looks at the battery life left on the phone. One bar. He then checks his watch. It's 8:19pm. Both are not good signs, and he knows it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh shit. He begins to panic. Grabbing the pocket knife that was left inside the metal box, he slides the blade in the space between the sides of the coffin and the top. Paul grabs the glow stick. But, because it was partially melted to the floor, the stick snaps in two. Liquid oozes out of the small portion of the stick that remains stuck the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son of a... Paul grabs the flashlight. Turns it on. It works for a second, but then goes out. Shaking it only produces intermittent beams of light. He turns the top, switching to the red bulb. It works. The coffin fills with a reddish hue, but then it, too, goes out. Growing incensed, Paul switches back to the white bulb. It works. He returns his attention to the coffin. His efforts to use the knife as a fulcrum are futile. Still, he tries. Bending the blade well past its design, it nearly breaks off its handle. The flashlight turns off. After a good shaking, it turns back on, emitting white light. With oxygen levels extremely diminished, efforts of this kind are all too much for Paul to take. He has to stop and try to catch his breath. As he endeavors to get his wind back, the cell phone rings. Not a call this time, but instead a video message. It has been sent by Jabir. Paul's trepidation is evident. He fears what the incoming video may show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . After a beat, he presses the Accept button and the video downloads. Within seconds, the video plays on his phone display screen. We see, in the video, the American Woman that previously appeared in a picture message that was sent to Paul. She is still bound at her wrists, but her gag has been lowered. She sits on her knees. Standing behind her are three men, all with their faces shielded by Arab headdresses. They each hold AK-47 assault weapons. Paul watches in horror as the terrified woman speaks, through her tears, into the camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is Pamela Gorham. I'm a food service worker at F.O.B. Anaconda, employed by Crestin, Roland and Thomas. My captors' requests for ransom have gone unanswered, and -- The Woman, Pamela, looks off-screen to her right. Someone is fast approaching her. She cowers, protectively holding her bound hands in front of her face as she screams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the person) No...wait!! Please -- no!! Another Iraqi man steps into the camera's line of site, a handgun already brandished. Without as much as a moment's hesitation, he fires two rounds directly into Pamela's head, killing her. The video message ends immediately thereafter. Paul is in complete shock. He screams aloud, slamming his closed fist against the bottom of the coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! No, no, no!!! Still in the throes of emotional torment, Paul vomits on himself. He doubles over, only to vomit once again. His body, taxed almost to the point of complete physical breakdown, gradually slows and levels itself. With his vomit- smeared face pressed cheek-down onto the bottom of the coffin, Paul stares into nothingness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . After a beat, his eye catches a glimmer of light -- the blade of the knife, reflecting off the beam of the flashlight. Paul reaches for the knife. Lying on his back, still suffering enormous mental strain, he places the cutting edge of the blade against his neck. His jugular vein. His hand shakes, his lips tremble. The hand that holds the blade tightens its grip on the handle. It, too, shakes. Paul closes his eyes. A small amount of blood begins to drip from the side of his neck, where the blade of the knife rests, ready to open his vein. After a great deal of consideration, Paul throws the knife to the foot of the coffin. He can't do it. The flashlight falls from Paul's chest. It turns off upon landing on the floor of the coffin. Paul sits in darkness. His breaths echo off the coffin walls. After a beat, he turns on the flashlight. It turns off after less than two seconds. This time, however, he does not shake it, nor does he hit it. A moment later, we hear a click, followed by the sight of a red light beam emitting from the flashlight. It holds steady. Paul shines it onto the names and phone numbers written on the top of the coffin. He stops at "MARK WHITE." After a beat, he lowers the flashlight to his side. He picks up the phone and dials Brenner. After one ring, Brenner answers. He's clearly not pleased. Paul, however, is surprisingly calm. Detached. Almost disturbingly so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why the hell did you make that video?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all a bunch of lies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is? What are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody gives a shit about any of us. We're nothing to you people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to find you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By looking the other way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't start breaking on me now, Paul. You have to stay strong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You let her die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a beat) No I didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shot her...and you didn't do anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We didn't even know she had been taken hostage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sent three videos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what they told her to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That your ransom video already has
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hits on YouTube. And all the major networks are playing it, including Al Jazeera. So, now your captors have no choice but to follow through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found out the number to this phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found a way to change the display language. I figured that out, and you didn't. Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I didn't. Just like you and every other person on this planet, there are some things I know and some things I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then how are you ever going to find me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their signal was cloned, like we figured. But, we're close. Real close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about mine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're working on that, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm near a Mosque. I could hear the call to prayer over the P.A.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. That means that we're in the right area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're nearby?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I spoke with soldiers from the third ID who were escorting your convoy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're alive? After a beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not all of them. Both Bradley tanks were hit with IEDs. The rest got caught in small arms fire. (BEAT) What the hell happened out there, Paul? Paul doesn't answer at first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul. After a beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We had just left Anaconda, everything seemed okay. We knew that a bunch of our CB radios had been stolen and that the Iraqis were listening in, so we made sure to switch from our usual channels. Pam was riding with Jeff Breer, the convoy commander. She wanted to ride with me like she usually did when she hitched a ride from base, but it seemed safer for her to be with the C.C. As we headed down the road, all these kids came running into the street. Dozens of them. It almost seemed like they were expecting us, except we got there faster than they thought we would. So they run on up in front of me, and I slam on my brakes. The rest of the drivers were already further up ahead, so they kept going. Next thing I know, one of the lead trucks got hit by an
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . I hear Tommy Wilkes on the radio saying, Sandman's hit, Sandman's hit. He's...he's everywhere. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's when the Iraqis came out of their mud huts from the side of the road and started shooting everybody. I couldn't believe what was happening. It seemed like slow- motion, like I was watching it on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . People -- my friends -- were getting killed, and all I could do is watch. I didn't even notice that the kids were throwing bricks and rocks at me until one split my windshield. Sort of snapped me out of my trance. But then, I guess I got hit in the head with a rock, `cause I blacked out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you happen to remem...mo... nea... The cell phone service begins to cut out. Suddenly, the coffin begins to vibrate slightly, dropping sand granules through the crack and onto the wood bottom, followed by the faint sound of an explosion. Within seconds, the explosions grow louder and more proximate. The vibration becomes so intense that it violently shakes Paul around the coffin. The sound of jet plane engines are heard coming from above, flying by as the massive explosions continue. Sand seeps in through the crack between the top and sides of the coffin as it shakes. Paul does his best to brace himself, but the bombardment is far too powerful. A large crack forms in the wooden cover to the coffin, spanning almost its entire length. Sand immediately pours through the concave shaped crack, seeping in onto Paul like an hourglass. Fearing that the top of the coffin may collapse under the immense pressure from the sand above, Paul positions himself underneath it and presses with all his might. He grunts and screams loudly, using what little strength he has left to keep the top from caving. The shaking soon stops, though the steady flow of sand continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . In efforts to prevent the sand from filling the coffin any faster, Paul removes the button-down shirt from the hole and stuffs into the area where it enters with the greatest volume. He removes the balled-up cloth from the other hole and does the same with it. Both offer very little help. The flashlight falls to the floor. The red light beam turns off. Darkness. The sound of sand steadily pouring down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no...no... Paul clicks the flashlight to a different setting. White light shines, but then goes out. He shakes the flashlight and it stays on, shining its normal white beam. He assesses his situation, noticing that the coffin is already filled with a small layer of sand; a situation that is only going to get worse with time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This can't be happening. We see that Dan Brenner is no longer on the phone, and that the display menu shows an icon of a phone with a line through it -- No Service Available. Once he feels it is secure enough, Paul slowly moves his body away from the crack. Although slightly caved, it does not show any more signs of possible collapse. Sweat drenches his face. His eyes affixed, in utter disbelief, on the sand as it spills into the coffin, filling in around him inch-by-inch. He grabs the cell phone, only to see that he does not have a signal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Come on. Please work. He shakes the cell phone and moves it all around the coffin, hoping that it may somehow help. His efforts are futile. The flashlight goes dead. He hits it, shakes it. It turns back on. The brightness is diminished. Still the sand continues to fall, drowning him deeper and deeper in a pool of granules. Then, very surprisingly, the cell phone rings. Paul answers right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Hello? Who's there? Alan Davenport answers calmly from the other end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this Paul Conroy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Yes, this is Paul. Who are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul, my name's Alan Davenport, I'm the personnel director here at Crestin, Roland and Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I left you a message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did. I also heard from Rebecca Browning over at the State Department. Are you able to speak on the status of your situation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's worse. There was an explosion or something. The coffin's breaking, there's sand pouring in from everywhere. I only have a half an hour before -- ALAN DAVENPORT Okay, okay. Slow down. You should try to stay calm. Tell me something, Paul, who have you spoken to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hostage takers, Dan Brenner from the hostage working group -- ALAN DAVENPORT Okay, Paul. I'm with you. How about the media. I know your ransom video leaked, but have you spoken directly to anyone about what's going on? The flashlight goes out. Paul hits it a few times and it turns back on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good. It needs to stay that way. It's important that we keep this situation as contained as possible. Paul finds Alan's obvious concern with doing damage control to be infuriating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About three inches to my right, there's a wall. Three inches to my left, there's another wall. And about four inches above my head, there's a roof that's about to collapse and drown me in sand. I think this situation is pretty contained.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you're upset -- PAUL Help me! Help me! What are you going to do to help me?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you're upset. And, from what I've been told, steps are being taken to get you out of there. So, hopefully it won't be much longer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, thank God. (BEAT) I'm going to switch on a recorder right now. Just a second... Paul's visage expresses his confusion. A click is heard in the b.g. of Alan's phone, followed by a low, steady hum. Alan's speech becomes very laconic. His questions are clearly being read from a Human Resources handbook of some kind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Alan Davenport, Personnel Director for Crestin, Roland and Thomas, Incorporated. The date is October 23, 2006. I am speaking with Paul Conroy. Mister Conroy, are you aware that I'm recording this conversation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please answer the question. The flashlight goes out again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit. Paul hits it, but it does not catch. He sits in darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mister Conroy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Yes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And do I have your permission to do so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you need my permission? What is all this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need you to answer yes or no, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Alright? Yes! Paul hits the flashlight. It turns back on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Now, Mister Conroy, when were you hired by CRT?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About nine months ago. Around January of 2005. Why are you wasting time with this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have your official date of hire as January 4th, 2005. Is that correct?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who cares? This is fucking crazy -- ALAN DAVENPORT January 4th, 2005. Is that correct?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And during your initial training, before being sent to Iraq, were you made aware of the dangers inherent to the position for which you were hired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean when I came down there to Dallas and you guys said that all of the trucks would be armored and have bulletproof glass? The flashlight dims. Paul angrily shakes it, returning it to full strength.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean when you told us that things were safer than ever over here? Is that when I was made aware?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need you to answer yes or no, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. The flashlight begins to slowly dim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During that time, did you also receive and sign an employment contract with CRT, which thoroughly explained company policy as it pertained to your specific terms of employment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I signed a bunch of things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes or no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I signed the contract. Yes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's our understanding that you were taken hostage in Iraq two hours ago, is that also correct?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. That's completely correct. What is the point of all this? Alan breaks from the H.R. handbook script, though his tone remains just as matter-of-fact. The flashlight continues its steady, slow dim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our legal department requires that we obtain a sworn affidavit from employees, confirming that they understand the reasons for their forced separation from the company. As of this morning, your employment with CRT was officially terminated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait, wait, wait -- The flashlight dims even more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was brought to our attention that you were engaging in relations with a fellow CRT employee -- Pamela Gorham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Wait -- ALAN DAVENPORT Stipulated in your contract was a fraternization clause, in which it was stated quite clearly that any relationship, be it romantic or sexual in nature, deemed inappropriate by CRT senior officials is grounds for immediate termination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We...we were just friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our records indicate differently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is bullshit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're also legally required to inform you that because you were technically no longer under the employ of CRT at the time of your abduction, we cannot be held accountable for any injury that may befall upon you after your official date and time of termination. Therefore, in your case, that includes this incident or any consequences that may result from it. Paul sees where Alan is going with this. He's thunderstruck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about my insurance money? My family will need that money...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Given that you were alive up until the time of your termination -- PAUL You son of a bitch. You can't do this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you understand everything -- PAUL You can't do this! Alan takes a second before trying again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you understand everything you've been told, Mister Conroy? Paul does not answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mister Conroy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . After a long beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to hell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That concludes our interview with Paul Conroy. I am now turning off the recorder. A click is heard. The humming ceases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You people can't just wash your hands of this. You bastards put me here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Alan ends the call. Paul looks at the phone -- it is still holding a steady signal. Battery life, however, is running quite low. All that remains is one blinking bar, indicating that Paul has very little battery life left. He shakes his hand free of the pile of sand that now covers it and looks at his watch. It's 8:31pm. The flashlight bulb dims until it goes out completely. Only the light of the cell phone display lights the coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on... Wasting little time, Paul dials Jabir. The phone rings and rings, but Jabir does not answer. Checking to make sure the he dialed the correct number, Paul matches it against the phone number he wrote onto the wall of the coffin. Seeing that he did, in fact, dial correctly, Paul again tries to call Jabir. While he waits through the many rings, he tries relighting the Zippo. Spark...spark...it catches. No one answers. Paul's disquietude is evident in his increasingly erratic behavior.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Answer the phone!! Paul tries Jabir once again, but still he does not answer the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (desperate, exhausted) Why won't you answer?!! It's then that something occurs to Paul. He stares at the crack in the top of the coffin and the sand that pours in at an alarmingly fast rate. The crack has split Jabir's written phone number in half. The aerial bombing. He wonders how it may have affected Jabir and, consequently, his own chances of survival. He places his hand under the point from where the sand pours in most, allowing it to collect on his palm and slip through his fingers. The flickering Zippo flame tells of the diminished amount of oxygen. Paul attempts to control his breathing, realizing full well that there are not many more breaths he will be able to take. He then calls Dan Brenner. After a few rings, Brenner answers. Paul is surprisingly serene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul, is that you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three F-16s levelled parts of the city a few minutes ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. I felt it. Did they know I was here? The Zippo flame flutters. Weakens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a beat) Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did they care? Dan does not answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These people that took me -- if they're dead, they can't tell you where I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can still try to track down your signal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You tried that already.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can try again. Paul appreciates Dan's effort, but he knows there is little hope left for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's over, isn't it? After a long beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Paul doesn't say a word. He knows that Dan is lying. After a beat, Dan comes clean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. The flame of the Zippo becomes smaller. It clearly has little life left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What should I do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right -- just like everyone else on the planet, there are some things you know and some things you don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish this could have gone differently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah...me too. After a long beat, Paul ends the call. He forces a smile to his lachrymose face. Utterly hopeless, he opens the phone and turns on the video feature. He turns the phone to face himself, projecting his image on the display. He presses Record.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Paul Steven Conroy. Social Security number 048-32-1198, date of birth 3/19/68. This video will serve as my last will and testament. To my wife, Linda Conroy, I leave the seven hundred dollars in my personal savings and whatever I have left in my annuity. To my son, Shane Conroy, I...I don't know. I don't have anything else. My stuff, like, my clothes. I wish I had more...I wish I had done more. Your dad wasn't really much of anything, Shane, I'm sorry. Maybe if I was a famous baseball player, or a guy who wore a suit to work, I would have more to leave you. But, you can be one of those people if you want. You can be whatever you want. Just promise me that when you get older, you'll take good care of your mom. And promise me that you'll always try to do the right thing, no matter what. I love you very much, Shane. Maybe I never said that enough...maybe I did, I don't even know. That probably means I didn't. (BEAT) I'm sorry, Linda. I should have listened to you. Paul ends the video and closes the phone. He carefully places the phone into his pocket, where it may hopefully be found if he ever is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He lays back, staring at the almost completely extinguished Zippo flame, as the sand continues to rain on him. Down and down it pours, the sands of time passing might and main through the cracks. The Zippo flame goes out. Paul sits in the darkness, resigned to what apparently will be his fate. Hold on black for several seconds...until -- -- suddenly, from inside Paul's pocket, he hears a faint vibration. It's the cell phone. He looks at the number of who is calling him. Shines the light of the cell phone on the list of numbers written on the top of the coffin. He can't believe what he's seeing. Paul answers immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not dead. Jabir is heard speaking frantically in Arabic to the several other people in the room with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Hello?! Jabir turns his attention to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is money?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What don't know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know where the money is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liar!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not lying! I swear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sounding panicked, Jabir again speaks in Arabic to the other people in the room with him. They respond accordingly. Paul tries to turn on the flashlight. It doesn't work. Jabir returns his scornful attention to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From Embassy, you get money now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need more time. Please. Paul shakes and hits the flashlight. It still does not work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No more time!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's sand pouring in here. I can't...it's everywhere. Please, let me out of here and I will get you the money. Jabir utters something in Arabic to someone standing next to him, seemingly asking a question and getting an answer from the same individual. Paul unscrews the top of the flashlight. Switches the positioning of the batteries. Screws the cap back on. Hits the switch. Nothing. Jabir returns to the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You show blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Paul unscrews the top of the flashlight again. Removes the batteries. Bites down on them a few times. Blows hard inside the flashlight tube.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You show blood, they give money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cut off thumb finger, send video.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not doing that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes! Paul puts the batteries back inside the flashlight. Begins screwing on the cap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, no. You let me out of here, and I'll cut off my whole God damn hand if you want. Jabir again says something to someone in the room with him, returning to Paul after a brief moment. Paul finishes closing the top of the flashlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have wife? Click. The flashlight turns on! Paul considers Jabir's question to be a potential sign of compassion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I do. And a son. A young son. I want to go home...to see them. Please, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Sir. I say that out of respect...to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: East Walnut Street. Hastings, Michigan. U.S.A.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's my...why did you say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You show blood...or they show blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's...you're lying. You're nobody...all of you. You can't get to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. You're peasants, criminals, that's all. You don't even know where Michigan is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Detroit. Ann Arbor. Even this basic knowledge is enough to make Jabir's threats that much more real.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You looked at a map. That's all you did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You show blood, or they show blood. Send video by five minutes. Jabir ends the call. Realizing that Jabir is gone, Paul quickly dials his wife's cell phone. After several rings, her voice mail picks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Hi, this is Linda. Please leave a message. Thanks and have a great day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Linda, listen to me: you and Shane have to go somewhere... anywhere. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't stay at the house, whatever you do, do not stay at the house. The guy...the kidnapper, he knows our address. He stole my license and now he knows where we live. Go to the Sheriff's station if you have to, just don't go home. Paul hangs up. He takes a moment to look around, noticing that the coffin is almost halfway filled with sand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (re: the sand) Holy God. Paul then dials Dan Brenner. After only one ring, the call goes directly to voice mail. The flashlight starts to dim. Paul shakes it, causing it to regain its strength.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Daniel Brenner. Please leave a message at the tone. The beep sounds. Paul delivers a frenzied message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brenner, where are you?! He's alive! He just called me! Call me right away! The fucking guy is still alive! Paul hangs up the phone. Unsure what to do next, Paul's heartbeat races. He fidgets, nervously shaking and tapping his thumb against the phone. He questions the validity of Jabir's threats toward his family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They can't find them. They...can't. There's no way. Paul opens the phone and brings up the photo of Pamela, bound and gagged. The image causes Paul to second guess himself. The flashlight goes out. The cell phone's display illuminates Paul's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He then replays the video in which Pamela is seen being shot. Reliving the experience is extremely painful, though his concern is more on his own family at this point. However, the video is enough to convince Paul of Jabir and his cohort's convictions. Paul tries the Zippo. Nothing. Only sparks. He tosses it aside. His breathing grows erratic and labored. His eyes dart from side-to-side, his throat groans involuntary noises of fear. Paul then looks at the knife, and then at his watch. He has less than two minutes to send the video to Jabir. Fearing for the safety of his family, he must meet Jabir's demands. He hits the flashlight a few times. Click. It turns on. Paul opens the phone and sets it to take video. He places it flat onto the surface of the sand, which by this point is already filling the coffin halfway. He then reaches for the knife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God. Oh my God. He places his hands against the side of the coffin, spreading his fingers. He stares intently at his thumb. With the extremely sharp knife in hand, Paul slowly lowers it just above his thumb. He inhales and exhales deep breaths, almost hyperventilating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holy shit. Paul then reaches into the sand and finds one of the expired glow sticks. He shakes the sand off of it and places it across his mouth, biting into it hard. His heart races, his breaths are the deepest he's ever taken. After placing the flashlight on the ground, to ensure that the camera picks up the image, he presses the record button on the cell phone. Grinding his teeth into the glow stick and letting out a primordial scream, Paul closes his eyes and chops down with the knife. We see, through the display screen of the phone, Paul sever his thumb with a swift chop of the blade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A small spray of blood spatters onto his face as he screams out in unfathomable pain. He falls to his side, still screaming and writhing. He reaches for his discarded outer-shirt, which is still stuffed in the crack to help slow the influx of sand. Removing the shirt from the crack instantly causes the sand to fall into the coffin more rapidly. Paul wraps the shirt around his hand. The blood quickly soaks right through it. He is fading fast. His blood loss is great. Shock sets in. He musters up the strength to send the video to Jabir. To secure his shirt over the wound, Paul removes his belt from his waist and pulls it tight over his wrap. Growing increasingly more pale, Paul teeters on the verge of consciousness. Everything becomes blurry to him. The phone falls from his hand. He shivers. His lips turn a light shade of purple and his face ash white. Everything becomes more and more blurry. He fights with every last ounce of strength to remain conscious. While laying against the side of the coffin, the phone vibrates once again. To Paul, the vibration against the wood seems so distant, so foreign. The vibration grows louder and louder in his mind, sounding more and more like the sound of rotating helicopter blades. He then hears what sounds like VOICES, yelling from on top of the coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's down here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get him out! Keep digging!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul, we're here! The cacophony of voices form a mosaic of sound in Paul's head, each overlapping the other in distant echoes. Shovels, digging deep into the ground, are heard banging against the top of the coffin. The top of the coffin is torn open, sending a brilliant ray of white light onto Paul. He stares into the light, crying, eking out a tortured smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Suddenly, Paul is back in the same predicament. The voices, the shovels, the light -- it was all a hallucination, brought upon by his loss of blood. He's still alone. He's still in the coffin, which continues to fill up with sand. He is too exhausted to display his disappointment. The phone continues to vibrate. It soon stops. Paul is in too poor condition to show any concern. After a beat, the phone begins vibrating once again. After several rings, Paul languidly picks it up. He barely recognizes the number through his extremely blurred vision. He's so weak, he's barely able to formulate words. He spits out stray particles of sand from his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul, it's Brenner. Paul doesn't have the strength to answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul? Are you there? Paul?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm...here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're coming for you now. You hear me? We know where you are. This news serves as somewhat of an adrenaline rush for Paul, who musters up even the modicum of strength he seemingly did not have left in him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're coming?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are, Paul. We're almost there now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coalition forces picked up a Shiite insurgent just outside of Baghdad. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Said he knew where an American was buried alive. He agreed to show us where if we let him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're coming for me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're practically there already. An impossible smile fights its way to Paul's lips. His momentary joy is just that, however, for the sand has almost completely filled the coffin by this point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No...you have to hurry. The sand...it's filling up fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just hang in there for three more minutes. This will all be over soon, I promise. Paul is very hopeful that Dan is correct in his assumption.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. I believe you. Thank you. Thank you. A beep is heard. Paul has another call coming in. He's visibly elated upon seeing who it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three minutes. Try to -- PAUL I have to go!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul, no -- PAUL Call me right back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call me right back. Paul switches to the other call, despite the fact that he has a mere eight inches left before the entire coffin is filled with sand from top-to-bottom. He holds the flashlight just above the top of the sand pile, allowing it to illuminate what little unoccupied area remains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Linda. Linda is in hysterics, which is evident in her speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul? Paul is that you? Tell me it's you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me, sweetie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God, Paul! What are they doing to you? Please tell me you're okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm...okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just saw the news. What...oh my God, baby. The flashlight dims. Paul shakes it, regaining a bit of its strength.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's going to be okay now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I missed all your calls. I left my cell phone at home. I just found out what was going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's okay. It's all okay. They're getting me out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The people. Americans. They found out where I am and they're on their way to get me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are? Oh thank God. Oh dear God, thank you. The flashlight flickers. Paul hits it. It flickers some more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all going to be okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know for sure? Oh God, please tell me you're okay. The flashlight continues to flicker almost like a stroboscopic light from this point forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was so afraid I was going to lose you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not. Linda breaks down in joyous tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you so much. I love you so, so much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you, too. (BEAT) I'm sorry. I should have listened to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't matter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should have never come here. You were right. I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sweetie, I don't care. I just want you home. Please come home to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will. I swear I will. Paul then receives a call on the other line. He checks to see who's calling. It's Dan Brenner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're calling me right now. I have to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call me right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will. I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you. Swear it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I swear. I have to go. Paul clicks over to the other line, where Dan Brenner waits to speak with him. We hear Dan yelling to people who are with him. A great deal of commotion and action is heard through the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Move! Move! Let's go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brenner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul? Paul?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're here! Dan yells to one of the soldiers who are with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Corporal, get your men over here! Dan gets back on the phone with Paul
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He brought us right to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the soldiers) Start digging! Let's go, let's go! The flashlight fades. Paul hits it, momentarily returning it to full strength. Meanwhile, the sand inside the coffin has almost reached the very top. It continues to pour in from the crack, seemingly faster than ever. Paul struggles to keep his head above the sand, giving him only a few inches between his face and the top of the coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to hurry. It's almost full.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just hang in there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurry! Please!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the soldiers) Dig! Dig! Dig! Paul fights to keep his head above the sand. The flashlight dims.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't...are you close?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're almost there, Paul. We're almost there! (to the soldiers) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Faster! (TO PAUL) We're almost there. We're right above you. The level of sand grows even higher. Paul spits away falling sand that threatens to suffocate him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't hear you! Where are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're almost there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is heard OFF-SCREEN in the b.g. of Dan's phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) There it is!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the soldiers) Keep digging!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurry! Please!!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the coffin! Just hang in there!! Paul coughs out sand. He has a mere inch left above his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurry! Where are you? I don't hear you? Please hurry!!! The Soldier is again heard OFF-SCREEN in the b.g. Of Dan's phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's clear!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the soldier) Open it! Nondescript noise is heard through the phone, until it comes to an abrupt stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God.
direction.name: direction
